NEW YORK Whitney Young,
executive director of the National
Urban Leagu and league trustees
issued a strong letter concerning
freedom of residence and the part
played by the real estate lobby
in defeating the Fair Housing Act
in California.


A copy Of the letter was sent to
President Johnson.


1t continued a paragraph deal
ing with segregation being fos-
tered by the National Association
of Real Estate Boards which en-
force slums and blight in our
cities.


The null trustees commended
the Housing and Home Finance
Agency for halting federal funds
for urban renewal programs in
California until a court ruling
is received.

League Trustees
ScoId Real
Estate Board

NEW YORK = United Negro
College Fund will distribute
$500, 1000 to 81 member colleges
and universities in ii southern
states this week, James r.
Smothers, Jr., vice-president for
development, announced.


UNCF has been conducting an
nual campaigns for member col
leges and universities since 1914,
when it raised S765 900. The goal
for the 1864 campaign Is
So 100000. Money from annual
funds Is used for scholarships,
faculty salaries and opeating
expenses.


Member colleges and univer-
stiles in the states of Georgia,
North Carolina, Virginia, Ala
bama and Tennessee will receive
the largest amounts from the
distribution.


Texas, Louisiana, Mississip-
pi, Florida, North Carolina and
Arkansas will also benefit.

COLUMBIA, Mo = The NAACP
will soon begin campaign to cor
rect inadequate treatment of the
Negro in textbooks used in the
public schools in Missouri. Re-
vision of such textbooks can be an
important steptowards removing
barriers to racial misunder-
standing.


In resolution pa ssed at the
annual meeting of the Missouri
State Conference of NAACP
delegates voted to launch a seven
pronged attack on the problem of
inadequate treatment of Negroes
in school textbooks.


Delegates attending the meet
ing spent an entire afternoon dis
cussing Textbooks as Tools in
the Good Society,"" The study,
prepared by Mrs. Irma Rinehart,
a St. James, Mo-, teacher, under
the direction of Professor
Lorenzo Greene of Lincoln Uni
versity, presented for the first
time an analysis of the treatment
of Negroes in textbooks used
in the Missouri public schools.


1t revealed that of l2o books
studied, the great ma jority was
found totally inadequate in con-
tent and treatment of Negroes
and their contributions to the
growth and culture of this
country.

The new column appearing IN the Phoenix
daily newspaper OY1tten by Ueteyun chill rights
leader, Roy wilkins, a Negro, Shoa0s that pro-
gYess in the field of journalism is rapidly being
made.


Wilkins started as a young reporter and
wY5teY in the midwest. He served for many
years in various offices Of the National ASso-
citation for the AdUancena ent Of ColoYed
People before becoming the national exec
utiUe secretary more than a decade ago.


The Phoenix Gazette is to be commended for
bringing this column to all its readers. More
persons of other ia cial and religious groups
should read some 1Oo1thaOhile words of re cog
nized Negro leaders. 1t is step fo1zOayd IN
1the entire field Of journalism - as the Roy
wilkins column appears, perhaps 1t min be
a first for a syndicated column by a member
of the coloYed race.


Mr.. Wilkins views from his widespread
ciuil rights activities coupled with his neUs-
paper bo ckgYourad should prove excellent
mate rial for anyone int rested in meaning
t74l interpretations Of today's world.
